extracted_outputs: Professor Admits to Killing His Girlfriend by Calling 911
University Professor Shannon Lamb, who called 911, told the police that he had shot his girlfriend with a gun and that the police should come to the house with his voice only a little shaky.
Lamb said that the "adorable dog" was alive and probably upset and that the family of the dead woman could be found by calling the woman's cell phone.

The police found Amy Prentiss's lifeless body in the house and a note written in handwriting on a white notebook: "I'm very sorry, I wish I could turn back time, I loved Amy, and she was the only woman who loved me until today" the officers said the note was signed by Lamb.

There was no indication that Lamb, who teaches two online courses for Delta State University in Cleveland, Mississippi, had driven the 300 miles to the school's campus where police believed he shot and killed beloved history professor Ethan Schmidt in front of his office.
Delta State University police chief Lynn Buford said university officials heard shots at 10:18 a.m.
Lamb also said that she made the fateful 911 call shortly after that.
At the end of the day, there was one more death: Lamb committed suicide as the police approached him.
One day after the school shooting caused students and professors to hide behind locked doors, officials were still trying to figure out what drove Lamb to do this.
Interviews with investigators on both sides of the state, as well as with students and staff who knew her, paint a picture of a talented but likely troubled teacher.
The students said that they were eagerly looking forward to his class.
A police officer in Gautier, where Prentiss died, said Lamb had no criminal or court record.
Schmidt even referred to Lamb as one of the "wonderful people" he shared his academic life with in a book he wrote.
Both had taught in the Social Sciences and History Department, where 17 faculty members were listed, and many students took classes from both of them.
There were also signs of mental problems.
Brandon Beavers, one of the students who praised Lamb, said that he was also worried and tense, and that he looked like he had a problem.
Another student, Mikel Sykes, said Lamb had told him he was struggling with stress towards the end of the 2014-15 academic year.
Lamb had previously requested sick leave from Delta State University, where he had some health issues.
This year she was giving only two courses over the internet.
Recent changes in the university's hiring policies did not automatically guarantee Lamb a tenure-track position, despite her hard work toward earning her doctorate.
University Dean William LaForge said he did not know of any problems between Lamb and Schmidt, but that "it is obvious that Lamb has some things on his mind."
These are questions that Lamb can no longer answer.
After the campus was evacuated, the police tracked Lamb's journey from Arkansas to Mississippi.

Washington County District Attorney Methel Johnson announced that Lamb had killed himself with a single .38-caliber weapon in the backyard of a home about a mile and a half from his family's home in the suburbs of Greenville, Mississippi, before he could be arrested.
Lamb's car was found to be working on the highway.
While it was not immediately clear why Lamb went to this house, Johnson said he believed that Lamb knew the people who lived there.
Lamb grew up in this region.
Lamb started working at the university, which has 3,500 students in the town of 12,000, in 2009, teaching geography and education.
He had got his doctorate in education in the spring.
One of Lamb's old friends described him as smart, charismatic and fun.
Carla Hairston said she was 15 and Lamb was 20 when they met through mutual friends.
Carla and her friends were in high school, and Lamb was that older, cool guy who was trying to teach himself how to play guitar for a few years.
Back then, he was one who made hearts beat fast.
Hairston, who is now 40 and lives in the Jackson suburb of Brandon, said of Lamb, "When he came, all the girls melted."
Lamb and Prentiss had clearly been together for some time.
Although Lamb said "I killed my wife" in the 911 call, there is no official record of their marriage.
They had a dog called Lightning living with them in the brick houses on the side of a river in Gautier.
The police said that the dog was in good health.
Prentiss' ex-husband Shawn O'Steen said that they divorced 15 years ago but they remained friends and they have a 19-year-old daughter.
O'Steen also noted that his daughter was completely devastated.
He and his mother were great friends.
He said he had never met O'Steen Lamb, but he had heard from his daughter Abigail that Lamb was interested in music and played the blues.
Lamb and Prentiss met three years ago when Lamb and Abigail appeared on stage at a summer festival.
Then Lamb and Abigail played together in general shows.
O'Steen indicated that her daughter wrote and sang her own music.
Prentiss was a nurse who worked for various online companies.

Mike Shaffer, the bartender and sometimes entertainment coordinator at The Julep Room, a dimly lit bar near Gautier, said he last saw Lamb and Prentiss on the evening of September 5 after Lamb had finished playing guitar and fiddle for a small crowd.
There was no sign of a problem.
They said they were a very happy couple.
Sometimes we would cut and throw a line to each other.
They both had a great sense of humor.

Don Allan Mitchell, an English professor at the same university, said that Professor Schmidt directed a seminar program for first-year students and was an expert on American Indians and colonial history.
He was married and had three young children.
He graduated from Emporia State University in Kansas and he was also president of a student solidarity group he founded.
Nearly 900 people attended a candle-lighting ceremony at Delta State University in Cleveland on Tuesday night, including academics, university staff, students and visitors from the local community.
Schmidt's wife Liz and his brother Jeff Schmidt also attended the memorial service, during which the university choir sang "Bright Morning Star" and "Majestic Simplicity."
Classes continue on Wednesday.
LaForge said, "We are trying to get our students back."
The crisis is over.
It's time to wrap up the wounds.
Amy and Rogelio Solis, of Cleveland, Mississippi, reported.
Associated Press writers Emily Wagster Pettus in Greenville, Mississippi, and Rebecca Santana in New Orleans contributed to this report.

This news text was changed to reflect that although the police say that Lamb called 911 after Schmidt killed Lamb and Lamb referred to Prentiss as his "wife" in the 911 call, there is no official proof that the two are married.
Toys R Us Plans to Hire Fewer Holiday Season Workers

Toys R Us announced that it will not hire as many holiday season employees as it did last year, but the toy and baby products manufacturer company said that it would offer more working opportunities to its current employees and to seasonal workers.
The company said it plans to hire 40,000 people at its stores and distribution centers around the country, up from 45,000 during the 2014 holiday season.
Most of the jobs will be part-time.
The company said that interviews with the candidates will start this month and the number of employees will increase from October to December.

While the holiday season is still months away, the holiday shopping season is approaching, and companies are gearing up to hire temporary workers to help them stock their stores, ship and deliver products.
Michael J. Fox Jokes About His "Relationship" with Princess Diana
The premiere of "Back to the Future" was a very important moment for Michael J. Fox.
It was also very important for personal reasons.

He tells this in the trailer of the documentary Back in Time, which will be shown soon: "We were waiting for the members of the Royal Family to come to the cinema, and suddenly I saw that the seat next to me was empty and realized that Princess Diana was going to sit next to me.
The film began and I realized that I was but a false stretch and arm's length away from dating the Princess of Wales.

Back in Time, a documentary about the Back to the Future film, includes interviews with Fox, Lea Thompson and Christopher Lloyd, as well as director Robert Zemeckis and executive producer Steven Spielberg.
Back to the Future was first released 30 years ago.
Spielberg said "This is the most exciting time travel movie I've ever done."
Back in Time will be shown in selected cinemas as well as in VOD and DVD formats.
UN Başkanı Suriye'de Askeri Bir Çözümün Olmadığını Söylüyor

Speaking about the increasing military support Russia is giving to Syria, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said that the Syrian problem, which has lasted for about five years, cannot be solved with military intervention and that more weapons would only mean more violence and pain for millions of people.
The UN Secretary-General also urged all parties, including the divided UN Security Council, to come together and engage in constructive dialogue to find a political solution to the problem.

Ban said at a press conference Wednesday that he plans to meet with the foreign ministers of the five permanent council members -- the United States, China, Russia, Britain and France -- ahead of the General Assembly meeting at the end of the month.
The council members expressed deep regret that the split between council members and the Syrian people had made the issue “unsolvable” for regional powers.
Ban called on the five permanent members to unite again as they did in the Iran nuclear deal.
8 Poll Numbers That Show Donald Trump Is Serious
Some tried to label him as a volcano.
The others laughed at him.
And some of them support the internal explosion.
Some Republicans have tried to drive Donald Trump down in the polls, but it hasn't worked (yet).
The most recent 11 national polls show him leading Donald Trump by double digits, and some are seriously asking whether the real estate mogul has a chance at the nomination.
Of course, it is still early in the election cycle.
None of this means that Trump can win the Republican nomination.
Experts say that in 2011, Rick Perry's rise led to a rise for Herman Cain as well, even though neither of them won a single state in the nomination process.
And there are many reasons why she will be in trouble in the general election.
But outside groups like Jeb Bush's Super PAC and the economic conservative group the Club for Growth are seeing Trump's staying power and spending their dollars to knock him down.
Here are some recent survey results showing that the real estate emperor is not just passing through:
Trump's approval ratings have changed 180 degrees.
A poll conducted at Monmouth University just before Trump announced his candidacy in mid-June showed that two in 10 Republicans had a positive view of the real estate mogul.
In the middle of July, this rate was 40 percent.
It was 52 percent at the beginning of August.
Now six out of ten Republicans have a positive view of Donald Trump.
Roughly 10 of them have a negative opinion.
And these numbers are high in the early stages.
Last week, a poll by Quinnipiac in Iowa showed that 60 percent of Republicans there preferred Donald Trump.
Two thirds of GOP voters could be satisfied with Trump's candidacy.
In a CNN/ORC poll last week, 67 percent of Republicans said they would be "enthusiastic" or "satisfied" if Trump were the nominee.
Only two out of ten people said that they would be upset if that candidate were to run.
Only Ben Carson generates the same level of enthusiasm as Trump (43 percent say they would be enthusiastic about him, compared to 40 percent for Trump).
The next closest person to the excitement?
Marco Rubio with just 21 percent.
On the other hand, 47 percent of Republican voters say they would be "disappointed" or "upset" if the party's favorite, Jeb Bush, were to run.
Most Republicans do not see Trump's temperament as a problem.

While Donald Trump is criticized for his flamboyant language and insults, according to a recent ABC News/Washington Post poll, 52 percent of Republicans surveyed think the real estate mogul has the right temperament to be president.
The same figure is valid in Iowa, where the party's first caucus will be held, and according to Quinnipiac's poll last week, 52% of the Republicans think that he has the personality to lead.
He still thinks that 44 percent do not have an effective personality to serve and according to ABC/Post, six out of ten independents say that his character does not suit the White House.
Republican voters are getting used to this idea.
When political experts put on their pundit hats, Republican voters think Trump is serious.
According to a CNN/ORC poll last week, when asked who would be the best candidate to win the GOP nomination, four out of 10 people said Trump.
A change from the end of July, when four out of ten people put their money on Jeb Bush.
Full disclosure: In the past, the GOP crystal ball was not very clear.
During the last cycle, four in 10 Republicans thought Gov. Rick Perry would run, while only 28 percent picked the eventual nominee, Mitt Romney.
It is still seen that the majority of GOP voters find Trump's election campaign plausible.
Even if Republicans coalesce around another candidate, Trump still beats almost everyone.
Some experts also point to the fact that the field is fragmented, which could help Trump, and it's true that anti-Trump support is spread among more than a dozen candidates.

But a Monmouth University poll released at the beginning of September shows that in a possible head-to-head match-up between Trump and several Republican contenders, Trump wins the majority of the support every time.
He beats Carly Fiorina by 13 points, Marco Rubio by 14 points, Walker by 15 points, Jeb Bush by 19 points, and Rand Paul, John Kasich and Chris Christie each by 33 points.
Tied with Ted Cruz.
The only candidate who can beat him?
In a hypothetical head-to-head matchup, Ben Carson beats the businessman by 19 points.
The majority of Donald Trump's supporters say they have made up their minds.
A new CBS/NYT poll released on Tuesday shows that more than half of Trump voters say they have locked in their votes.
Frankly, a lot can happen to change it and no one can really say that nobody will change their mind.
Forty-six percent said they would keep the door open to change their mind.
Still, Trump's biggest rival is brain surgeon Ben Carson, but voters who say they have made up their minds are twice as likely to vote for Trump.
Six out of ten Republicans say they agree with Trump on immigration.
Ever since Donald Trump called Mexican immigrants "rapists" in his campaign announcement speech two months ago, immigration has been at the center of the 2016 conversation.
Some think that Trump's talk is alienating important Hispanic voters from the Republican Party and damaging his attempts to rebrand.
But according to a new ABC/Post poll released Monday, six in 10 Republicans said they agree with Trump on immigration issues.
So as long as the issue of immigration stays on the agenda, it seems like Trump will also stay on the agenda.
The anger towards the government is rising to new heights.
Donald Trump and Ben Carson are roughly taking half of the Republican votes because of their outsider status.
In a new ABC/Post poll conducted Monday, six in 10 Republicans said they wanted someone from outside government rather than someone with government experience.
And they are angry with Washington.

A Des Moines Register/Bloomberg poll two weeks ago in Iowa showed that three out of every four Republicans in Iowa were angry with Republicans in Congress, with 54 percent "dissatisfied" and 21 percent "extremely angry."
Jeremy Corbyn will take the podium for the first time in the Prime Minister's Questions
Since the day he was elected, Mr. Corbyn's appearance in the Prime Minister's Questions program was eagerly awaited
Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the New Labour Party, will take the podium in the Prime Minister's Questions for the first time after David Cameron.
Mr. Corbyn will ask six questions in a short while, and his performance is expected to be scrutinized closely by the media and Labour MPs.
In a weekly show, he made a call for "less theater and more truth."
He also said that he could skip some sessions by leaving them to his colleagues.
This will be the first parliamentary test of Mr Corbyn's leadership, following his shadow cabinet appointments and his speech at the TUC annual congress on Tuesday.

In the meantime, the Labour Party leader`s silence during the playing of the national anthem at the commemorative ceremony held on Tuesday to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain was criticized by some Tory MPs and was the focus of front-page news in the newspapers.
Mr. Corbyn's decision not to sing the national anthem drew attention.
A spokesman for Mr Corbyn said he stood in "respectful silence" and "recognised the heroism of the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain".

But Owen Smith, a member of Labour leader Mr Corbyn's shadow cabinet, told the BBC's Newsnight programme he would advise the Labour leader to sing the national anthem "independently" of his belief in abolishing the monarchy.

While a dozen shadow ministers refused to serve in Mr. Corbyn's top team because of differences on economy, defense and foreign policy, less than a quarter of the parliamentary party backed him as leader.

BBC political correspondent Robin Brant says there are also differences within the Labour Party "piling up", including over Mr Corbyn's position on the European Union and the government's cap on benefits.
Mr Corbyn told the TUC conference that Labour would offer new changes to scrap the cap entirely.
Hours later shadow work and pensions secretary Mr Smith said the party was only opposed to the government's plan to cut the upper limit from 26,000 £ to 23,000 £ and was "very clear" on this.
Mr Corbyn will be the fifth Labour leader to face David Cameron across the dispatch box since he became leader of the Conservative Party.
The Labour leader promised a different approach to politics and said he had asked the public for "crowd-sourced" advice, receiving more than 30,000 suggestions.

Islington North MP Jeremy Corbyn said the Question Time programme was too "polarising" and would focus on poverty, inequality and the problems faced by young people rather than "answer-making" and "needling" exchanges.
Mr Corbyn said that in the absence of himself, for example, when Mr Cameron was abroad, he would be represented by shadow trade secretary Angela Eagle in the Prime Minister's Questions programme.
At times, he has even suggested that other colleagues should take the floor and he has said that he has approached the Speaker of the House of Commons, John Bercow, to address the issue.

When he became leader in 2005, Mr Cameron said that he wanted to move away from the "puppet show" style of politics associated with Prime Minister's Questions, but admitted a few years later that he had failed to do so.

Since its first broadcast in 1990, the Prime Minister's Questions has been used as a key benchmark to measure leaders' decision-making ability, dominance in the House of Commons, and their standing among MPs; however, some critics have argued that it has been caricatured and that it needs a comprehensive reform.
'Shot in Joburg': Homeless young people learn photography
Johannesburg city center is a tough place for the homeless.
But a group of former street children found a way to make a living by developing a new talent.
I was shot in Johannesburg, at a non-profit studio that teaches homeless young people how to make money by taking pictures of their neighborhoods.
BBC News went to meet one of the first graduates of the project.

Sterling rises as wage growth in the UK accelerates
Following data showing increased pay in the UK, the pound rallied as the FTSE 100 index also rose after a takeover bid for SABMiller.
In the United Kingdom, wages excluding bonuses increased by 2.9 percent between May and July, compared with the same period last year.
This rate, which expresses the fastest increase since 2009, is also seen as one of the leading indicators for possible interest rate increases.
The sterling gained more than 1% against the US dollar to 1,5505 $ and gained 0.84% against the euro to 1.3730 €.
The FTSE 100 Index rose 1.49 percent to 6,229.21 points.
The most striking company in this rise was SABMiller, which recorded a 20% increase with its attractive acquisition offer from its rival AB InBev.
The deal will bring together the world's two biggest beer companies and unite well-known brands such as Budweiser, Stella Artois, Peroni and Grolsch under one roof.
Burberry shares rose 0.9% boosted by positive profit news from rival luxury retailer Richemont.
Richemont's current sales figures show that sales have started again in China, which is one of the key markets for Burberry, in addition to exceeding expectations.
Shares of mining giant Glencore rose 5 percent after the firm said it had raised $2.5 billion from a sale of shares to cut its debt.
Mondi, the packaging and paper group, was among the biggest fallers, down 4.3 per cent, after Goldman Sachs cut its recommendation on the company to "sell".
Shares in JD Sports rose 3.1 percent after the company said its pre-tax profit rose 83 percent to 46.6 million pounds in the six months to August.
The JD Sports boss said higher wages could damage expansion
JD Sports Chairman Peter Cowgill said that a higher minimum wage in Britain could mean "more spending power in the pockets of potential customers."
But he said that this spending power could not cover his high staff costs at his own company.
He also added that the costs will affect JD Sports' expansion plans and could mean less extra work.
Metcash launches a public campaign to fight against Aldi's invasion
Metcash is trying to protect its IGA stores in South Australia and Western Australia from an Aldi attack.
Wholesaler Metcash has launched a public campaign to defend its retail stores in South Australia and Western Australia against a $700 million Aldi invasion.

As Aldi is getting ready to open its first store and two distribution centers in South Australia and Western Australia at the beginning of next year, Metcash and IGA supermarkets are strengthening their relationships with local food suppliers and are trying to build the IGA brand with mainstream and social media marketing and events like the Adelaide show.

IGA retailers and suppliers are also contributing to the IGA stores, such as the Dunsborough-based ice cream producer Simmo, which offers taste tests in IGA stores, and store owners who sell discounted tickets to South Australian Football League to their loyal customers.
Food, drink and hardware wholesaler Metcash is expected to give more details on its defence strategy when it holds its annual investor day on September 29.
The risk is high because South Australia and Western Australia represent almost 30% of Metcash's IGA store footprint and deliver higher margins than Metcash's IGA network in the eastern states.

South Australian and Western Australian store owners are negatively narrow-minded and IGA retailers in NSW, Victoria and Queensland are enjoying a far stronger market share than they are in the Eastern states; 30% more in SA and 24% more in WA.

However, analysts like Morgan Stanley believe that Aldi will capture about 5% of the market within the first 12 months of opening its first stores in the two states and it will take sales from the existing players but generally independent retailers.
In a report published this week, Morgan Stanley analyst Tom Kierath forecast IGA retailers would lose $360 million over the next year and Metcash $250 million by the end of 2016.
This forecast is based on the estimate that Aldi will open 25 stores in GA and 30 in BA next year, with sales of $500 million and $600 million in each market.
Mr. Kierath said that the loss of food and grocery sales and Metcash's high fixed cost base could leave Metcash with an underlying pre-tax profit of about $13 million.
Despite a recent Roy Morgan survey that shows Metcash's IGA customers are the most loyal, it is losing market share in the eastern states, primarily to Aldi and Coles.
According to Morgan Stanley, Metcash's food and grocery sales will fall by 3.8% in 2016, 4.1% in 2017 and 2.1% in 2018, which will take its market share from 14% in 2015 to 10.3% by 2020.
Last week, the founder and chief fund manager of Magellan Financial Group, Hamish Douglass, said at a business dinner in Melbourne that Metcash is "likely to be wiped out in ten years".
Metcash declined to respond to Mr Douglass's comments.
But it is understood a Metcash board member contacted Mr Douglass last week.

IGA's market share has fallen from 18% to 14% since 2010, and Metcash's earnings from its food and liquor business that supplies about 1,200 IGA retailers have fallen 43% since 2012, an indication that the business leverage is diminishing as sales and margins come under pressure.

But the wholesaler is fighting back, spending more than $150 million a year matching shelf prices on hundreds of products a week at Coles and Woolworths, helping IGA retailers refurbish their stores, adding faster-growing fresh food and launching a better own-label supermarket range.

Metcash chairman Ian Morrice says pricing matching and store refurbishment programs are starting to pay off, and the wholesaler is expected to return to core profit growth for the first time in four years in 2017.
Thanasi Kokkinakis is supported by Tennis Australia president Steve Healy
Thanasi Kokkinakis deserves more praise than criticism for his behavior.

According to Tennis Australia president Steve Healy, Thanasi Kokkinakis was on the receiving end of collateral damage in the recent storm around his friend Nick Kyrgios and deserves more praise than criticism.

Kokkinakis, the younger member of the talented duo known as the "Special K's", found himself under the unforgiving spotlights after his compatriot Kyrgios humiliated Stan Wawrinka at the Montreal Masters.

In the demanding match played in Cincinnati in the afternoon, Kokkinakis and his opponent Ryan Harrison were separated twice by the referee, and Harrison made the following statement: "Wawrinka came to Kyrgios, so I had to go to that kid as well."
Kokkinakis, who was last seen at the US Open potentially spoiling Richard Gasquet's day by breaking his racket, was staunchly defended by Healy.
The young player is currently in Glasgow competing for the second singles spot behind Bernard Tomic against Britain in the Davis Cup semi-final alongside Sam Groth.
Healy said, "The thing that I feel very optimistic about is that Thanasi has gotten into the discussion."

When he was stopped in the US and lost, he broke his racket, but he was not the first player to break the racket because of his disappointment, and I know that Thanasi is quite aware that he should not be proud of this.
But in reality Harrison handled himself extremely well under very provocative conditions with the others in the US and I think he deserves a lot of praise for that.
He has a great team around him, a great family, and I think it's been blown out of proportion.

Despite his age, he is very mature and works hard and fits in with the team, he has no problems with other players, he is welcomed with respect in the locker room, he does the hard training, and he is a very balanced and mature young man and in my opinion, he deserves to be judged by his own standards.

Healy also backed the decision to welcome back Kyrgios for an important doubles, saying from Friday that the right thing for everyone is to "make mutual decisions" but support him to come back as a long-term asset to the team.
Healy said, "Above all, we want the team to focus on the match and not on the controversy surrounding Kyrgios."

And in my mind, as people like Nick, Federer, Murray have said, the kid rose very quickly, grew up in front of the public eye, he made some awful mistakes and he deserved all the criticism that he got, but we are trying to support him, trying to help him understand the consequences of his actions and sometimes when he's not in the spotlight, I think deeply about what is good for him, the team and himself.
European migrant crisis: Hungary declares state of emergency, closes borders and detains migrants
Hungary declared a state of emergency on Tuesday in order to cut the flow of migrants and closed its southern border with Serbia, detaining those trying to enter the country illegally.
Chaos erupted at the border as hundreds of migrants piled up in the no-man's land and the Serbian authorities reacted angrily.
The immigrants, who fled from the violence in their own countries, set up tents on the roadside and settled in the tents for an indefinite period of time between the two countries' control points.
But their anger was growing.
As a police helicopter flew overhead, migrants shouted "Open the border!" and hurled insults at the Hungarian riot police.
Some of them refused the water and food given to them as a protest.
The Serbian Foreign Minister said that it is "unacceptable" for Hungary to send back migrants as the flow of migrants from Macedonia and Greece continues.
(Serbia) wants to be a part of the solution, not part of the problem.
Ivica Dacic Pragda said that there will be meetings with Brussels and other countries in the coming days.
The tension at the Hungary-Serbia border came just one day after the 28-nation bloc failed to agree on a common refugee policy at a meeting in Brussels.

The ministers agreed to share responsibility for the 40,000 migrants who were flooding into Greece and Italy, and they spoke hopefully that Eurozone countries would agree to accept another 120,000 migrants, including those from Hungary, over the next month or by the end of the year.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Austria called on Tuesday for an EU summit next week to discuss the migration crisis facing the continent.
Hungary, however, is not hopeful that Brussels or its neighbors will take any concrete steps on the issue.
The emergency decree issued in two southern regions on Tuesday gives authorities wide-ranging powers to deal with the crisis, including closing roads if necessary and speeding up asylum cases.

On the other hand, Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said his country plans to put a barbed wire fence along its border with Romania as well to stop the flow of migrants from this country after he put a fence along its border with Serbia.
CBS News correspondent Charlie D'Agata reported that even prisoners are being recruited to work on putting up the barbed wire between Hungary and Serbia.

In the last few months, Hungary has become an important bottleneck and transit point for migrants to the European Union, and most of these migrants are refugees fleeing wars in Syria and other Middle Eastern countries.

Prime Minister Viktor Orban is insistent that most of the arriving migrants are "economic migrants" trying to get to Europe for a better life, not innocent people fleeing war, a view that is completely at odds with the views of other EU countries including Germany.

The laws that came into effect at midnight in Hungary not only make it a crime to breach or damage a 4-meter-high (13 foot) fence along the Serbian border, but also introduce tougher penalties for human traffickers.
In the southern city of Szeged, government spokesman Zoltan Kovacs told reporters, "Due to the situation caused by mass migration, the Hungarian government is declaring a state of emergency."
On one thing we are very clear: crossing the border illegally is a crime.
While the deployment has yet to be approved by parliament, Associated Press reporters in the region say they have seen heavily armed soldiers with dogs and vehicles for days.
Orban's domestic security advisor Gyorgy Bakondi said that the authorities had caught 45 people trying to cross the border and 15 people who had crossed the border and entered the country.
They cut through the barbed wire, now they are under police custody, and they are accused of committing a crime under the new laws.
The authorities are quickly repairing the barbed wire.
Hungarian authorities also closed two of the seven border crossings with Serbia on Tuesday morning, using a train carriage covered with barbed wire to close one of the crossings.
Chaos spread to the main border crossing near Roszke as the Hungarians brought in a small metal container in which people were packed tightly to process them.
While 20 people could get in, thousands were left outside.
Another group of migrants blocked the road linking Serbia and Hungary and said they would not accept food and water until they were allowed to enter Hungary.
Election 2016: Hillary Clinton's lead over Bernie Sanders cut in half in national poll
Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton continues her double-digit lead in the Democratic race for the presidential nomination, but Sen. Bernie Sanders is closing the gap.
Clinton is currently receiving 47% of the Democratic votes (down from 58%), while Sanders is in second place with 27% (up from 17%).
Vice President Joe Biden, who has not yet announced whether he will run for president, is getting 15 percent of the Democratic vote.
In the five months before the primaries began, most Democratic voters said it was too early to decide which candidate to support.
But Clinton supporters have more solid ideas about their own choices than about other candidates.
Since last month's CBS News poll, Clinton has lost ground among a number of demographic groups, while Sanders has made some gains.
Clinton is way ahead among women and moderates, but that gap is closing.
Support among men has dropped significantly, and Sanders now trails by only 5 points.
Clinton's advantage among Democratic voters under 50 has evaporated, and she and Sanders are now in a dead heat.
But Clinton is way ahead among older voters.
Last month, Clinton was leading Sanders by double digits among liberals, but now Sanders is ahead by five points in this group.
At the national level, about half of Democratic voters say they would enthusiastically support Clinton if she were the nominee.
A quarter supports him under certain conditions, while a 15 percent portion will support him only if he is the candidate.
Six percent of the population does not support Clinton.
Perhaps not surprisingly, Clinton's current supporters are especially inclined to support her passionately.
Views among those who do not currently support Clinton are even more mixed - only a quarter of them could back her passionately.
While 48 percent of Democrats say they will enthusiastically support Clinton, they are talking less about their Republican counterparts' front runners, Donald Trump (35 percent).

When her supporters were asked open-ended questions about why they want Clinton to run, the top answers were that she has the right experience (16 percent), that it is time for a woman president (13 percent) and that she is the best candidate for the job (10 percent).
Clinton's supporters also mention her relationship with Bill Clinton (9 percent).
Being conciliatory in problems and being electable are among the criteria listed.
As a vice president with potential to be president, 57 percent of Democratic voters may be willing to see him in the race, but a third of the electorate does not think that way.
When democratic voters are asked who is their second choice for the party, Biden is at the top.
More than half of Clinton's supporters say that Biden would be the second-best candidate, by far, according to Sanders.

If Biden does not run for the Democratic Nomination, Hillary Clinton's lead over Sanders increases; in a race with Biden, her level of support is 20 points, but in a race without Biden, it increases to 30 points.
Fifty-five percent of Democratic voters see Clinton as the candidate with the best chance of winning the general election; however, that number has dropped from 78 percent last month.
Biden, who is second in this regard, is far behind, but the percentage of those who see him as the most electable candidate has increased.
When asked what was the most important thing about a candidate, Democratic voters put issues ahead of electability.
As was the case last month, no Democrat voter candidate or candidate candidate seems acceptable to the primary voters.
Democratic candidates or candidates act well in some main characteristics among the first voters of their own parties.
The majority see Clinton, Sanders and Biden as honest and trustworthy, as well as having strong leadership qualities.
Biden is first in terms of honesty, while Clinton is strong in terms of leadership.
Thirty percent of Democratic voters say Clinton is not honest and trustworthy, while half as many say the same of Sanders (15 percent), while 27 percent have no opinion on the issue.
Democratic voters also generally see Clinton, Sanders and Biden as in line with their ideology.
By all measures, a quarter of Democratic voters have no opinion of Sanders.

While questions continue about her use of a personal email address and server during her time as Secretary of State, most Democratic voters say they find her explanation on the issue satisfactory and that their views of her are unaffected.
But this is a different story in the general American public.
While half of Americans are no longer satisfied with his explanations, only a third find them satisfactory.
The public opinion on this issue split shortly after the issue was brought under the spotlight in March.
Most Americans say the email controversy has not changed their overall opinion of Clinton, while 36 percent say it has given them a more unfavorable view.
These are generally Republicans, and more than six in 10 say their views of Clinton have worsened.

While Clinton is still seen as honest and trustworthy by voters in her own party, it is still a problem among registered voters overall: only 32 percent see her as honest and trustworthy, a drop of 8 points from last month and 15 points since May.
Sixty-two percent of registered voters do not find him honest and trustworthy.
At the same time, 55 percent of registered voters throughout the country do not also find Trump honest and trustworthy.
However, both Clinton and Trump receive good grades for leadership.
Among the six candidates who took the test, Biden, Carson and Bush got the best scores for honesty.
More of them find Sanders honest, but like Carson, most of them do not have an opinion about him.
The margin of error for the 351 Democratic samples is 6 percentage points.
Ben Carson is right behind Donald Trump in national polls.
According to the latest CBS News/New York Times poll, Ben Carson is running a close second behind Donald Trump.
The new poll shows that about half the voters cast their ballots for one of the two candidates, and the other candidates have no chance.

Nationwide, Republican voters continue to support Trump in large numbers, with support rising from 23 percent in the last CBS poll before the debate, on Fox News, to 27 percent in a new poll released Tuesday.
But support for Carson rose from 6 to 23 percent during the same period.
The poll also found that Carson is doing quite well among demographic groups, with support among college-educated Republican voters much higher than Trump's.
The rest, except Carly Fiorina and Ohio Governor John Kasich, dropped from 10 percent last month to 2 percent.
Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee and Florida Senator Marco Rubio are in third place with 6%.
This most recent poll, conducted with 376 Republican voters, has a margin of error of plus or minus 6 percentage points and was conducted in September.
The latest CNN/ORC poll released last week showed Carson's support among the Republicans at 19 percent, just behind Trump's 32 percent.
The latest poll by ABC News/Washington Post also shows Trump significantly ahead of Carson.
Last week, faced with Carson's rise, Trump apologized to the retired neurosurgeon for questioning his faith, but he kept on randomly poking at him.
At a campaign stop in Iowa on Saturday, Trump said, "We need energy."
Five fraternity members charged in death of Baruch College freshman
Nearly two years after a college student died during a fraternity pledging ritual in the Pocono Mountains of Pennsylvania, five people were charged with murder.

Members of the New York City Baruch College Pi Delta Psi fraternity savagely attacked Chun "Michael" Deng during a hazing ritual in September 2013 and, according to police, delayed taking him to a hospital, contributing to his death.

Authorities said his eyes were blindfolded, a 30-pound sandbag was strapped to his back and he was constantly tripping over a sturgeon carcass as he tried to walk across the frozen field to his target.
Mr. Deng said that his head was hurting and then he lost his consciousness.
Members of the Pi Delta Psi fraternity did not call 911 after Deng collapsed, and they waited an hour before taking him to the hospital, according to police.

However, according to the Police Commissioner Chris Wagner, who spoke at the press conference, they changed Deng's clothes, searched for symptoms on Google and contacted the national chairman of the sorority, Andy Meng, to ask for advice.
Detective Wagner said at that point that members began to store personal items and had put the well-being of the fraternity ahead of Michael Deng.
He could not be resuscitated and died the next morning.
According to an autopsy report, Deng suffered traumas caused by repeated blows with a blunt object to his head, body and buttocks.

Douglas Fierberg, an attorney representing Deng's family, said in a statement that 'as a result of fraternity initiation rituals, many families have been shattered and at least one student has died every year since 1970.'
Fraternities and their members should be held responsible for this and the step taken by the authorities is very important.
The grand jury in Monroe County recommended that third-degree murder charges be brought against the first five members.
Thirty-two members of the brotherhood, including Mr. Meng, will face trial for the attack and may also be charged with conspiracy.
Wagner said at a press conference on Tuesday that they will hold accountable not only those who are involved in the business, but also the organizations that approve it officially or unofficially.
Baruch College banned the fraternity, and the national fraternity severed its ties with the local chapter.
What happens when the Fed raises interest rates?
When interest rates rise, the bull market collapses and bond yields soar, the economy also records a decline.
We know this.
What we do not know is how long it will take and how long it will last.
History, especially in economics, offers very little information about timing.
The recession, which was as short as 11 months after the first interest rate increase, lasted as long as 86 months.
The aggressive nature of the U.S. Federal Reserve in raising interest rates has been a determinant in the reaction of the economy and financial assets, though not always.
This is why the Fed officials are stressing that investors should not focus on when rates will rise, but how long the normalization process will take.
It is a fact that there are various variables.
However, the result may be that the market participants think that the rate hike hysteria is exaggerated.

In a note to customers, Julian Jessop, chief global economist at Capital Economics, said, "It is inevitable that some will see the Fed's first interest rate hike since the global financial crisis as signalling the end of the era of cheap money."
On the contrary, we do not expect US interest rates to return to normal anytime soon, but it is seen that most of the low levels still remain a seismic shock to be feared.
Still, we cannot say that it will have no effects.
Based on past trends, the reaction that some sectors of the economy could give is as follows:
As seen in the past months, waiting for the interest rates to rise can sometimes unbalance things for a while.
The effect is not so significant when the interest rate is increased.

In a new study on what will happen after rate hikes, Deutsche Bank analysts say, "It is seen that there is a trend of a 12-24 month pause in core earnings following the first rate hike, which could reflect the pause in monetary policy."

According to a recent analysis shared by Bob Doll, an analyst at Nuveen Asset Management, in Barron's the market usually registers sharp increases during the last 35 years - an average of around 14 percent - and then moves in a straight line towards the interest increase 250 days later - an average increase of 2.6 percent - and then returns to normal and provides an average return of 14.4 percent in the last six cycles.
Deutsche said the effect on shares should become more pronounced in the later stages of the rate hike cycle and yield should disappear.
Setbacks are a fact of economic life, but interest rate increases help them.
The Fed is currently facing some circumstances that did not exist before and will accelerate the recession.
The most striking thing is that the gross domestic product is at its lowest level for the Fed interest rate increase.
According to Deutsche Bank, in 118 interest rate increases that happened since 1950, nominal year-over-year gross domestic product has fallen below 4.5 percent only twice.
Although the real GDP growth in the second quarter of 2015 was at 3.6%, according to the Atlanta Fed, this is expected to be short-lived, and the third quarter is forecast to increase at a 1.5% rate.
According to Deutsche, raising interest rates in such a sensitive economic environment could be risky and could lead to the question of "will it be any different this time?"
The attention of market participants who have been waiting for a year for the Fed to raise interest rates will be on the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which will end on Thursday.
While most strategists and economists believe the FOMC can approve a hike at this meeting, futures trading is pointing to only a 25 percent probability.

The report stated that "based on our investigations since 1950, all the expansionary cycles so far have been within the super-cycle of the rising trend and the domestic product has rapidly reached the peaks before the decline after the beginning of the recovery."
On the contrary, this is a recovery from a slump of unprecedented slowness in a period of exemplary growth.
The current cycle is the longest since the Fed has waited since the last recession — the longest cycle on record was 35 months and the current cycle is 74 months and still ongoing.
The fixed-income market became unstable with the expectation of an increase in interest rates in the market, and the order is a sort of like our own capital.
The real difference is that the effect is seen faster in bonds than in stocks when Fed policy changes course.
When the first increase/decrease in the cycle occurs, bond yields do not immediately change direction.
At the end of the rate hike cycle, bond yields go down immediately," Deutsche said.
According to the experts at Charles Schwab, the increase in interest rates will flatten the yield curve by bringing the returns on longer and shorter-term bonds closer together.
Kathy Jones, one of the Schwab analysts who said that we are saying that high-yield bonds generally perform better in such an environment, but "we are still cautious about reaching return".
Interestingly, Jones thinks that markets have already adapted to the Fed's policy expectations.
"In addition to the strength of the dollar and the decline in inflation expectations, there are various signals that the market is being reorganized according to tighter monetary policy," he wrote.
Short-term interest rates are rising, the yield curve is flattening, credit spreads are widening and volatility is increasing - all features that will be seen in markets when the Fed tightens policy.
Looking at it broadly, companies that do most of their business in the United States will gain as interest rates rise and local products become more attractive.

The situation of the heavily indebted multinational companies will be worse as the increasing dollar will make their products more expensive in the global market and their debts will be more expensive.
Goldman Sachs analysts said in a report prepared for clients that "history shows that 'quality' stocks can underperform at the beginning of such a run-up"
Firms with strong balance sheets outperformed those with weak balance sheets by an average of 5 percent after the 1994, 1999 and 2004 rate increases.
Companies with high-capitalization and low-volatility stocks also outperformed their low-quality rivals by an average of 4 to 3 percent.
The debt will become a big issue.
According to Goldman, the companies with high proportion of floating-rate debt are most likely to suffer.
Apart from the pure stock game, it is expected that consumers will also benefit from the increasing dollar.
Although experts disagree on how fast to go, savers can also profit from the high yields.
Andrew Bingham said BBC Radio 3 Classic FM was a clone
Conservative MP Andrew Bingham accused the station of 'going downmarket'
He argued that the radio was increasingly becoming similar to its commercial rivals.
He also accused the BBC Music Awards of targeting and undermining the Brit Awards.
His colleague Damien Collins, however, accused The Voice of being unoriginal.
A prominent MP has put pressure on the broadcaster to underscore its difference from other commercial stations by saying the BBC Radio 3 is increasingly becoming like Classic FM.
Conservative MP Andrew Bingham also told BBC bosses that the radio station was "going downmarket" and was increasingly indistinguishable from its commercial rivals.
"I don't like to use this expression but Radio 3 has gone "downmarket" and is gradually becoming like Classic FM" he said.
In addition, it also targeted the BBC Music Awards, which was held last December.
The BBC Music Awards, which were launched last year, is essentially another version of the Brit Awards.
"So if you're trying to do something different, these are the first two examples that come to mind, and instead you just go and copy something that's already in the market," Bingham said.
The general manager of the BBC rejected the accusations and defended that BBC Radio 3 is by far ahead of its commercial rivals in both live music and public education.
If I learn something about classical music from Radio 3, I don't go and learn something about it from somewhere else.
And this is the devotion to live music and making music is incomparable to anything else.
He also said that he thinks Radio 3's efforts to discover new music and promote the works are very important.

BBC Radio 3 controller Alan Davey claimed at the beginning of the year that the station needs to work harder than ever to reach more listeners, because Britons are less educated in the field of classical music.
However, Radio 3 was not the only element that was under fire at the Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee meeting because it is accused of stepping on the toes of its commercial rivals.
Tory MP Damien Collins also took a swipe at The Voice - the BBC's music talent show, which it bought from Dutch production company Talpa Media for £22million.
Can you not see why the program is making so much noise, because it is not original and has no special distinction?
Lord Hall insisted the BBC1 show, which is judged by Paloma Faith and Boy George, was made in a "distinctly BBC style".
He said that the institution should find a hit in its own blood before it produces another entertainment program.
However, he did not accept the idea of blocking the production of more The Voice programs in the future, or spending the money on other formats.
Is it the Black Friday in August that causes the lowest increase in internet sales in history?
In the first three months of 2015, there was a seven percent increase in online sales.
Last month, the lowest growth was recorded since 2000, when the records began to be broken.
Three years ago, when mobile devices began to be used in shopping, there was an explosion in online sales.
Experts say that Black Friday in November could be the reason for the drop in spending.
Online shopping has been booming for more than a decade, turning some of Britain's liveliest shopping streets into ghost towns.
After the figures showed only a seven percent increase in internet sales in the first three months of 2015, experts say that the internet sales are increasingly showing signs of weakening.
Spending in August increased by just five percent compared to last year and the lowest growth was recorded since the year 2000, when records started to be broken.
After the figures showed only a one percent growth in internet sales during the first three months of 2015, experts say that the internet sales are showing more and more signs of decline.

IMRG's sales index editor Andy Mulcahy told the Guardian, "If you look at the growth levels of previous years and in particular the year 2000, you see that everything has returned to normal over time."
He also added that the internet sales have seen a great increase three years ago, when consumers started using their cell phones to purchase products.
This meant that more people could shop while they were lying on the couch.
But right now it's flat, you can see the decline.
The Black Friday phenomenon, imported from America, is being cited as one of the reasons for the slowdown in sales.
Experts say that shoppers may be waiting for this event, which takes place on the last Friday of November, to buy something.
Last year, more than five times more consumers than the previous year flooded the websites of companies to grab the bargains, and many sites collapsed.
Experts say that Black Friday may have "temporarily" tamed shoppers as images showed them fighting for bargains.
A research published by the British Retail Consortium shows that every five pounds spent on shopping, one pound is spent on buying products from the internet.
One third of some products, such as TVs and washing machines, are now bought from internet stores.
In addition, more than a quarter of the people buy their clothes and shoes from the internet rather than from luxury and glamorous shopping streets.
Muslims bid farewell to those who lost their lives in the crane accident in Mecca after the Bin Laden family have been found guilty
After the first funerals held in Mecca, the bodies of the 29 people who lost their lives were carried through the streets by Muslims
Saudi Arabia holds construction giant Saudi Binladin Group responsible for the crane crash that occurred
The health ministry said a total of 394 people were injured after the scaffold collapsed.
Hundreds of Muslims came together to carry the bodies of 29 people who lost their lives when a crane collapsed in the Grand Mosque.
The majority of the crowd inside, the whites, blocked the roads to bid farewell to the last journeys of the first funerals at the Muaysim Cemetery in Mecca.
The mournful crowd passed the holy place where a few days before the tragedy occurred and the ceiling of a mosque collapsed and fell on the pilgrims.
In the incident, where 394 were injured, the bodies of the dead were brought to be buried after Saudi Arabia held the construction holding of the Binladin family responsible.
The bodies of 29 pilgrims who lost their lives when a crane fell at the Grand Mosque in Mecca were carried on shoulders along the road.
There was also Kasım Akram, a father of four from Bolton, Manchester, who was on his first pilgrimage.
Mr. Akram came to the Holy Masjid with his mother and father, at the beginning of the annual Hajj.
Saudi leaders announced that the pilgrimage would continue with the participation of thousands of pilgrims on the way to Mecca.
In a statement today, King Salman said that the Binladin Holding group should not have left the boom of the crane open when it was not in use.
The Arabic version of the decree prepared by the Saudi Press Agency, which is run by the state, says that Binladin Group is the only side to be blamed for the incident.
The English service of the news agency did not mention this detail, but it informed that the company officials were banned from going abroad.

On Monday, Salman pledged to find the cause of the collapse of a crane into the courtyard of the Grand Mosque of Mecca, where hundreds of thousands of Muslims come for the pilgrimage at the end of the month.
The Binladin group did not make any statement about the collapsed crane and did not allow their representatives to make any comments.
The royal decree accused the group of failing to take current security measures and to cooperate with meteorological authorities.
The Masjid al-Haram in Mecca is surrounded by dozens of cranes, most of which are managed by the Binladin Group.
The Binladin family has been close to the ruling family of Saudi Arabia for decades and is the name behind most of the construction projects.
Osama bin Ladin, the last leader of Al Qaeda, was also a wayward son disowned by the family.

The accident happened just a few days before millions of Muslims flock to Mecca, the holy city that every adult Muslim is obliged to visit at least once in their life, in one of the busiest times of the year.
Officials said 158 people are still being treated in hospital.
The authorities have ordered that compensation of 1 million Riyal (174,000 pounds) be paid to the families of the dead and those left permanently injured.
The other wounded will get half of this amount.

The boss of B&Q says that this trend is due to cheap Eastern European tradesmen.
```
Veronique Laury says that the British are increasingly hiring more craftsmen.
Behind this increase is the number of East European master craftsmen
As a result, 200 new Screwfix stores are being opened targeting tradesmen.
At the same time, Kingfisher is closing 60 B&Q stores across the country.
By: Rupert Steiner, Daily Mail City Editor
It is said that the British people have begun to hire skilled Eastern European craftsmen to do the jobs around their houses instead of letting the hammers and paintbrushes go.
If you are good at using a hammer or painting a wall, you are in the minority these days.
Because according to the boss of the company behind B&Q, Britons are increasingly hiring tradesmen to do DIY jobs in their homes.

Veronique Laury, the new chief executive of the home improvement chain Kingfisher, said the reason for the trend is a huge increase in the number of skilled Eastern European tradesmen offering services at low prices.
In the end, Kingfisher will close 60 B&Q stores and plans to open 200 more Screwfix stores aimed at tradesmen.
Mrs. Laury wants more women to be employed in B&Q stores because she said eight out of ten purchase decisions are made by women.
Currently, the majority of the staff are male.
The single woman home improvement house says that there is a need to meet the emerging demographic trends that are more home improvements than in the past.
Ms. Laury said "Most of our employees are still male in our stores.
We need to create more balance.
Basically, half of our customers are women and 80 percent of the purchasing decisions are made by women.
Women play a big role in the decision-making process.

Ms. Laury, one of the five women at the head of Britain's leading companies index FTSE100, has restructured her top management team so that it is comprised of an equal number of male and female directors.
Kingfisher, with its team of 50% women, including its CEO and Finance Director, is almost alone in the field.
Ms. Laury said, "It was a conscious decision - diversity is an important issue here.
It was not hard to find good women to join our management team.
After taking the cost of closing stores, Kingfisher announced a fall in both quarterly profit and sales.
As a result of the trend, Kingfisher, the owner of Screwfix and B&Q, will open 200 new stores.
It is time for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates

The Federal Reserve, which is holding its two-day meeting on Wednesday and Thursday, is being watched by the whole world; the decision on whether or not to raise interest rates after ten years is being awaited.

In a poll carried out by Reuters, more than half of the 80 economists said that the Fed would implement this decision last week, and now they think that the Fed will postpone this decision and hold the interest rates between 0-0.25 percent.
Since seven years have passed since the FED lowered the interest rates to zero, this is a historic event.

Angel Ubide, senior researcher at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, said, "For the first time, we will see a major central bank beginning the process of normalizing interest rates from zero."
The US economy is performing relatively well and trillions of dollars are being added to the balance sheet in the process of re-animating the economy and creating a little bit of inflation.
But the FED cannot ignore the less promising global picture.
The markets are warned of an increase, but there are indications that the situation does not allow for such an increase.
The decision will be announced on Thursday at 8 pm.
The perpetrator of the murder at Delta State University left a suicide note

According to authorities, on Tuesday, Shannon Lamb, killed his girlfriend with a gun in Mississippi on Monday morning and left a note saying he was "sorry" for the first murder and that he wished he could "take it back" before he killed a coworker later that day.
Mississippi Gautier police say Lamb called 911 around 10:00 a.m. She was an instructor in geography and social sciences at Delta State University.
Monday, and said that he killed one of them with a weapon.

I loved Amy and she was the only person who had ever loved me.
After writing the note, Lamb drove 300 miles to Delta State University in Mississippi, where he shot and killed history professor Ethan Schmidt, then killed himself when police closed in.

On Monday, Lamb said he had heard a report that Prentiss had an emotional relationship with Schmidt, but on Tuesday the authorities said they had "no information or evidence" of a love triangle.
Shawn O'Steen, who was married to Prentiss for about seven years, describes Prentiss as "a good guy".
The couple divorced 15 years ago, but their friendship has continued.
O'Steen said Prentiss has a 19-year-old daughter and that the girl is "devastated."
O'Steen also said that Prentiss and her daughter are "definitely best friends."
According to Lindsay Knowless, who the Sun Herald described as a close friend of Prentiss, Prentiss was working from home over the Internet.
Knowles says that Prentiss, who owns a hunting dog named Lightning, has been with Lamb for about three years.
Knowles said, "She always liked to help others."
Police said that Lamb called his relatives on Monday and said "I'm not going to jail."
That same night, police got close to him on Highway 1 near Greenville, and he pulled to the side, got out and fled into a wooded area, where he shot himself.
According to his CV, published on the university's website, Lamb received his PhD in education from Delta State University in the spring of 2015.

This incident, which brought tears to the defender's eyes, will keep him off the field for at least six months, but Louis van Gaal remains hopeful that Shaw will return to the field this season.

Surely David Cameron knows The Lorax better than that?
This is something every parent learns quickly: when your child loves a book, you know it won't take long to memorize it almost by heart.
It seems that if you are not David Cameron.
When asked by a holiday planner for childcare suppliers what his favourite children's book was, the Prime Minister chose The Lorax, Dr. Seuss' 1971 environmental fable.

Cameron continues as follows in the message published on the website of SuperCamps company: "I love to read this book to my children because it has a funny, compelling, creative and a powerful message, and it has an image or a message that is always skipped and kept in the background."

Everything was going fine until Cameron supposedly wrote something about the content of the book, but in reality new characters and details were added in order to blow up the original fairytale text's content, up to the paragraph that summarizes the 2012 movie version of the book.

In the walled city of Thneed-Ville, where all nature has vanished and even the air is a commodity, a boy named Ted wants to fulfill the wish of the girl of his dreams, Audrey, to see a real tree, writes a love story which includes a fairy tale that Dr. Seuss, whose real name is Theodor Seuss Geisel, who died in 1991, did not know.

If that weren't enough to raise some eyebrows, the text that Cameron tackles bears a striking resemblance to the synopsis of a movie called The Lorax on the Internet Movie Archive, which begins like this: "In the walled city of Thneed-Ville, where everything is artificial and even the air is a commodity, a boy named Ted hopes to win the heart of his dream girl, Audrey."

If we consider the claims that Cameron is a competent parent, it is highly unlikely that he is unaware of the main theme of the book in which a young boy, who is never named, hears how his local environment has been destroyed by greedy Once-lers, who cut trees, despite the objections of the Lorax, a short, bearded creature who "speaks for the trees".
Most probably, such a weak Public Relations work was assigned to a yes-man, who obviously did not read The Lorax to a child 20 times in a row.
One of the president's spokeswomen said that the text was thought to have come from Mr Cameron's election office.
SuperCamps confirmed that the text was supplied by Cameron's staff, but declined to comment further.

The decision to drop Adam Lyth is a tough one for me to analyse as head coach at Yorkshire.

There was no question mark over Joe Root, the announcement had to be made because - as I have said before - the players were the best selections.
After a few fifties, Lyth could have seen his career extended, but he determined his own fate.
I hope that he will catch another opportunity if he works harder for Yorkshire.
England coach Trevor Bayliss praised the player's attitude, which did not surprise me; after all, he is a team player.

Although everyone does not agree, the plans, coaches and players are not selected by the selectors.

If the economy remains stagnant until 2017, the Brexit camp could win.
David Cameron's half-baked strategy for keeping Britain in the EU is getting worse by the day, despite Jeremy "Yes or No?" Corbyn's election as Labour leader or the TUC's Tuesday meltdown on Europe.
Foreigners also have their Corbyns and Nigel Farages.

The Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister attend summits or bilateral meetings in the capitals of foreign countries, have their pictures taken in front of the famous monuments there, whether the locals are prominent or not, and then they return to their own country and say that they have collected allies for reforms.

"Renegotiation was a dead end" and "Britain got nothing out of renegotiation."

But Jeremy Corbyn, who patted me on the back amiably on Monday in Westminster, saying that he now had no more time to waste on me, seems to be in danger of adopting again the Murdoch-boycott strategy of the 80s, which was then and is still one of mistakes.

I'm being polite by describing Corbyn's official position in Europe as evolving.

This reminded me of my father's struggle in the 1970s with his colleagues in the cabinet for loyalty, for not going too far, and for losing his job in the cabinet.

Experts criticize the UK Public Health e-cigarette research
Researchers said that e-cigarettes are 95 per cent less harmful than smoking at a meeting of 12 people with links to the tobacco industry, which was funded by the government.
Experts writing in the British Medical Journal (BMJ) have joined Lancet in criticising the evidence used by Public Health England (PHE) in its report on e-cigarettes.
PHE published its "landmark" report last month, which it described as a "detailed examination of the evidence".
But some researchers questioned the reliability of the data and pointed to ties between some experts and the tobacco industry.
The Lancet medical journal last month targeted the "extraordinarily flimsy basis" of PHE's main conclusion in its lead editorial.
Two other researchers writing in the BMJ questioned whether the claims were built on sand or rock.

Martin McKee, professor of European public health at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, and Simon Capewell, professor of clinical epidemiology at the University of Liverpool, said: "The fundamental principle of public health is that policies should be based on evidence of effectiveness."
They said the public would expect PHE's claim that e-cigarettes are "around 95% less harmful than smoking" to be based on a detailed examination of the evidence and modelling.

Actually this is the result of a 12-person meeting assembled to develop a multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) model to form the synthesis of their views on the harms of these various nicotine-containing products; the results of the meeting have been summarized in a research article.

McKee and Capewell said that one of the sponsors of the conference was a company called EuroSwiss Health, which had been reported to have received funding from British American Tobacco for an independent study.
They also said that it had approved a public health promotion certificate for BAT in a sustainability report.

They reported that one of the 12 people at the meeting had funding from an e-cigarette manufacturer, but added that it was not the funding that was previously reported to have come from the Philip Morris International cigarette company.
No information was given on how the panel members were chosen, but some of them reported industry funding in the article, including some of the known giants of e-cigarettes.
Some other people present at the meeting are not known for their expertise in tobacco control.
The PHE tobacco control lead also attended the meeting.
McKee and Capewell acknowledge in the research paper written by the group that there is a "lack of concrete evidence" on the harms of most products "effectively" on many grounds.
But none of these connections or restrictions are discussed in the PHE report.
Mckee and capewell said that claims that there is no evidence that e-cigarettes are a gateway to smoking for children or non-smokers are premature.
Prof Kevin Fenton, director of health and wellbeing at PHE, said the BMJ claims had been addressed previously.
He said, "E-cigarettes are significantly less harmful than smoking."
One out of two lifetime smokers dies from their addiction.
All the evidence points to the health risks from e-cigarettes being much smaller than from smoking, but we need to continue to investigate the long-term effects.
PHE has a clear mission: to inform the public, especially at a time of great confusion about the relative harms of tobacco, about what the evidence does and does not show.
Nearly 80,000 people die each year from smoking-related illnesses and smoking costs the NHS £2 billion a year.
By clearly laying out the existing evidence - that e-cigarettes are not risk-free, but carry only a fraction of the harm caused by smoking - we are fulfilling our national responsibility.
Former Channel 4 boss says BBC should axe EastEnders

Former Channel 4 chairman Luke Johnson has said the BBC should stop broadcasting shows such as EastEnders and The Voice, and advert rivals could "give their right arms" for hit shows such as the Albert Square soap.
Johnson said the license fee should be used to make programs of a type that other British broadcasters are not making.

The BBC has been criticized for putting public service programs like BBC4, which have a lower chance of being viewed by a smaller group of viewers, against the competitors' most popular programs at regular intervals.

After the BBC's director general Tony Hall said the corporation wanted to work more closely with other organisations; Johnson said that he had tried unsuccessfully at Channel 4 to forge a link with the BBC for six years.

Johnson said he is struggling with the idea of the BBC commissioning and broadcasting programmes that can clearly be shown by un-subsidised rivals during a questioning about the future of the broadcaster by the House of Lords Communications Committee.
If you continue the license fee, which I am not sure is a good idea in the medium or long term, it should at least be reduced to programs that others do not make or order.
They broadcast The Voice in primetime because they want to draw as much support as possible for the future.
The main idea here is based on the idea that no one else will publish it, which is ridiculous and obviously nonsense.
Johnson said, "I don't understand why programs that can be funded without aid should be funded with a decreasing proportional tax.
The Voice is one, EastEnders is another, and it is actually done in the company.
To be honest, other channels would give their right arms for this.
I am trying to see how the public service broadcasts are.
I don't think this will diminish the BBC at all.

Johnson, a serial entrepreneur who ran Channel 4 from 2004 to 2010, accused the BBC of chasing ratings "because of the passion of the people who work here and because those people see that approach as the best way to guarantee long-term support."

His comments about the BBC's most popular shows echo those of former Sky chief Tony Ball, who used his 2003 MacTaggart lecture in Edinburgh to suggest the BBC should sell off programmes like EastEnders.

Johnson said the BBC had moved more suitable public service programs to BBC4 where the audience measurement could not be done, but these covered the tax exemption and the nominal religious obligation to continue the floor of 4 billion sterling on the license fee income, and he added, "Of course, we also make all these silky programs that nobody watches."
They put them into empty spaces where no one will ever see them.
Regarding the licence fee, Johnson told the committee, "I invite you to find a more regressive system from the point of view of those who get the most benefit from it.

Of course you are thinking, all of us are thinking, 150 pounds a year is a great value, but I wonder if for people for whom 150 pounds is a great deal of money the reason for doing that is not watching too much of the BBC.
David Elstein, the former head of Sky and Channel 5 who also gave evidence to the committee on Tuesday, said the BBC needs to revise its Reithian mission to "inform, educate and entertain".

He said that some of the BBC's output is now officially classified as education - 1% of its TV output and 0.1% of its radio output - and that public service broadcasting in Australia and Canada should lead the way and that this should be reframed as "informing, enlightening and educating".

On partnerships, Elstein said that the BBC needs to do something about the Proms, which are only shown on TV in a handful, and to partner with the advertisers to make all of them available to be viewed online.
'Sonogenetics' enables brain cells to be controlled by sound waves.
In the video, it is seen how the spiders change direction when they are hit with the sound vibrations.
Scientists have bred crickets with genetically modified nervous systems that can be controlled by sound wave blasts.
The tiny thread worms change direction when they are struck by high-frequency sound waves that humans cannot hear.
They are operated by genetically modified motor nerve cells carrying zar channels that respond to ultrasonic waves.
Related: Researchers read and write brain activity with light
Researchers say the maggots have proven the power of a new procedure called sonogenetics, which allows ultrasound to activate a series of brain, heart and muscle cells from outside the body.

Sreekanth Chalasani, a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, California, told the Guardian that one day this procedure could replace deep brain stimulation, an invasive procedure that involves putting electrical pulses into people's brains to treat Parkinson's disease symptoms.
Threadworms don't usually respond to sound, but Chalasani found that they did respond when surrounded by a liquid containing microscopic bubbles.
The bubbles he finds strengthen the ultrasound waves and allow the mites to pass through the tick.
Augmented ultrasonic waves affect structures called TRP-4 ion channels, which are found in the membranes of some nematode cells.
According to a report published in Nature Communications, sound waves cause these ion channels to open and activate the cells to which they are attached.
To create the ultrasonically controlled silkworms, Chalasani genetically modified the worms so that some of their motor neurons carry the TRP-4 ion channels.
When ultrasound was applied to the modified creatures, the sound waves were amplified by micro-bubbles and transmitted into the maggots, where they activated the modified motor neurons.
This procedure has similarities to optogenetics, a groundbreaking tool that allows scientists to turn neurons on and off with pulses of light.
But Chalasani says that sonogenetics may have some advantages over the technique.

Unlike light, which needs to be sent through an optical fiber to the desired point in the brain, low-frequency ultrasound waves can pass through tissue without obstruction, and thus can be sent into the brain through the skull.

Chalasani said, "We believe that using gene therapy and a therapeutic virus, we can make human neurons targeted for specific neurological therapies temporarily sensitive to ultrasound in the clinical environment."
He added that other applications could focus on muscle cells and insulin-producing cells.
